Vanderbilt’s strength rests on inclusive excellence and the vigorous exchange of ideas. Imposing a strict cap on international student enrollment—especially at such a low percentage—risks constraining the very intellectual diversity and civil discourse that animate our campus. To sustain a community enriched by a broad range of perspectives and knowledge systems, Vanderbilt should remove such caps and maintain a holistic, country-agnostic admissions approach that welcomes talented students from all nations. Removing race- and gender-conscious approaches from admissions and hiring risks narrowing the university’s capacity to identify promising talent that has been historically unseen, under-resourced, or structurally excluded. A great research university thrives when it gathers people whose perspectives have been shaped by different histories, neighborhoods, and educational pathways; absent intentional attention to equity, many of those voices never make it to the table. Vanderbilt should keep these policies of admissions and employment to keep these chances. Taking punitive action against departments for holding views perceived as inconsistent with conservative ideals and enforcing protest restrictions that curtail students’ ability to express dissent risks undermining core principles of free expression and academic freedom. Such measures edge toward illiberal control rather than open inquiry, narrowing the range of debate precisely where universities should cultivate good-faith disagreement. Vanderbilt, as well as its staff and students, should be given free will to take a side on certain issues. Accordingly, I urge Vanderbilt to advocate forcefully for revisions that advance the interests of students and faculty—or, failing that, to withhold its signature.

Some concerns:  - Standardized test requirements: Not everyone has equal access to standardized tests. The SAT and ACT both come with fees, and fee waivers only cover up to two takes of these tests. Requiring standardized tests creates a disadvantage for low-income students as, unlike high-income students, they do not have the means to take these tests frequently to get the scores expected at Vanderbilt. I was not test-optional, and fortunate enough to be able to take the ACT as much as I could, but knew several brilliant students in my rural Tennessee community who were limited by how many tests they could afford to take.  - Race/Sex in Admissions: I am a firm believer that admissions should consider the unique situation of every student. Students’ grades, test scores, and extracurricular opportunities that all play a role in their admissions success are heavily reliant on their personal circumstances. People are still discriminated against for their race or sex, which may have a negative effect on their circumstances. I am a white woman, so any consideration of race or sex in admissions would likely be a net neutral for me, but I believe not considering the unique situation of every student paves the way to elite schools like Vanderbilt being only accessible to those who aren’t disadvantaged, creating education gaps and homogeneity of ideas on campus.  - Definition of Sex:  Whether the government acknowledges it or not, modern academics of social sciences and biology have agreed that sex and gender are separate and gender is a social construct. To use the administration’s definition that conflates the two, we restrict our top academics and researchers in social sciences to conform to a notion that has largely been accepted as incorrect in their fields. If we restrict the university’s academics and researchers from teaching and articulating the latest knowledge in their fields, then we jeopardize Vanderbilt’s position as a leading university. - International student cap and “foreign ties”: The United States should take pride that its universities attract students from all over the world, not discourage it. Though I am not an international student, I believe their presence on campus is nothing but beneficial. Restricting and discriminating against international students restricts the diversity and amount of ideas and knowledge that we have at Vanderbilt, which should instead promote diversity of ideas as a learning institution. - Free-speech, neutrality, and anti-conservative departments: I don’t believe that we need to double down on policies that are “against disruptions that block classes or events” as this is vague and can and will be used against student protestors by the government, especially since the compact demands DOJ overreach into the school. Barring anti-conservative views but not anti-liberal views is also contradictory to neutrality. - Expand tuition waivers for “hard-science” majors: As someone who is an engineering major, something likely considered “hard-science”, this policy would only benefit me. I still strongly disagree with its implementation as students should not receive different treatment based on their major. It supports the narrative that social sciences or other fields of study are not as important as ‘actual science’, which is far from the truth; even as an engineering major, I would not be where I am at today without the critical thinking and writing skills I developed in my social science courses. Students will be discouraged from applying to non-“hard-science” majors which would create a surplus of “hard-science” majors. This push by the government seems inconsistent with the policies they’ve already implemented: if this administration promotes a surplus of science majors while at the same time pushing policies that cut funding for scientific research, then it simply increases the amount of science majors who are unable to find jobs due to these cuts.
